unnormalised: Hey everyone, someone asked about common units used in medicine, especially here in India. It's a good question because sometimes things get a bit confusing!
normalised: Hey everyone, someone asked about common units used in medicine, especially here in India. It's a good question because sometimes things get a bit confusing!

unnormalised: So, you'll often hear about weight in kilograms (kg) or grams (g) when it comes to dosages, especially for kids. Like, "give your child 5 ml of this syrup, 3 times a day" – ml stands for milliliters, a measure of volume. If you're admitted to a hospital, your height might be recorded as 170 cms which is centimeters. Things like your blood pressure are measured in mm Hg (millimeters of mercury). I remember my grandma’s BP always hovering around 140/90 mm Hg!
normalised: So, you'll often hear about weight in kilograms or grams when it comes to dosages, especially for kids. Like, "give your child five milliliter of this syrup, three times a day" – milliliter stands for milliliters, a measure of volume. If you're admitted to a hospital, your height might be recorded as one hundred and seventy centimeters which is centimeters. Things like your blood pressure are measured in millimeter of mercury (millimeters of mercury). I remember my grandma’s B-P always hovering around one hundred and forty divided by ninety millimeter of mercury!

unnormalised: Another thing you'll see a lot is temperature – usually in degrees Celsius (°C). If you have a fever, the doctor will ask "kitna temperature hai?" and you'll probably say something like "101°C"…. well, that would be dangerous! Always double-check if they mean Fahrenheit (°F) or Celsius. Doctors in India generally use Farenheit when talking to patients and Celsius in the prescription.
normalised: Another thing you'll see a lot is temperature – usually in degrees Celsius. If you have a fever, the doctor will ask "kitna temperature hai?" and you'll probably say something like "one hundred and one degree Celsius"…. well, that would be dangerous! Always double-check if they mean Fahrenheit or Celsius. Doctors in India generally use Farenheit when talking to patients and Celsius in the prescription.

unnormalised: Then there are things like blood sugar levels, measured in mg/dL (milligrams per deciliter). A normal reading might be somewhere around 100 mg/dL if you are fasting. Body Mass Index or BMI is a very common way to calculate a healthy weight. Someone might say they have a BMI of 25 kg/m^2, which is calculated as weight in kgs/ height in meters squared.
normalised: Then there are things like blood sugar levels, measured in milligram per deciliter (milligrams per deciliter). A normal reading might be somewhere around one hundred milligram per deciliter if you are fasting. Body Mass Index or B-M-I is a very common way to calculate a healthy weight. Someone might say they have a B-M-I of twenty five kilogram per meter squared, which is calculated as weight in kilograms divided by height in meters squared.

unnormalised: Finally, when you're talking about eye prescriptions, you’ll come across diopters. My uncle's specs are -2.5 D on both eyes. Don't worry too much about the technicalities, just trust your Dr. and follow their advice! Hope this helps clear things up a little bit!
normalised: Finally, when you're talking about eye prescriptions, you’ll come across diopters. My uncle's specs are negative two point five D on both eyes. Don't worry too much about the technicalities, just trust your Dr. and follow their advice! Hope this helps clear things up a little bit!
